{{Infobox person | pre-nominals = Dr.(h.c.) | name = Abel Bosum | image = | native_name = | birth_name = | birth_date = November 4th, 1955 | birth_place = Dore Lake, Quebec, Canada. | citizenship = Canadian | education = | occupation = Grand Chief of the Grand Council of the Crees | employer = Grand Council of the Crees of Northern Quebec | predecessor = Grand Chief Coon Come | parents = Lucy Busom, Cypien Caron | honours = Doctor of Civil Law, Honoris Causa, from Bishop's University Order of Canada }}
'''Abel Bosum''' (born Nov. 4, 1955)<ref name=":1">Travers, E. (2000, Jul 11). Abel bosum: Quiet force behind crees' success. ''The Gazette'' Retrieved from <nowiki>http://www.ubishops.ca:2048/docview/433626075?accountid=8636</nowiki></ref> is a Cree leader and negotiator who is currently serving as Grand Chief of the [[Grand Council of the Crees]] of Northern Quebec. (Eeyou Istchee)<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/abel-bosum-grand-chief-cree-1.4221041|title=Abel Bosum new Grand Chief of Quebec Cree|work=CBC News|access-date=2018-02-14|language=en}}</ref> He has worked for the Grand Council of the Crees of Quebec since 1977 in various capacities.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.abelbosum.com/meet-abel|title=Abel Bosum for Grand Chief 2017 {{!}} Eeyou Istchee Quebec|website=Abel Bosum for Grand Chief 2017 {{!}} Eeyou Istchee Quebec|language=en|access-date=2018-02-14}}</ref> From 1984 to 1998, Bosum served as the Chief of his home nation the [[Oujé-Bougoumou, Quebec|Oujé-Bougoumou]] Cree Nation.<ref name=":2" /> During his time as chief, he was able to negotiate a multimillion-dollar deal with the governments of Quebec and Canada to build a new village for the nation following the peoples' seventh forcible relocation due to mining and forestry activity in Northern Quebec.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/181843232|title=Aboriginal autonomy and development in northern Quebec and Labrador|date=2001|publisher=UBC Press|others=Scott, Colin.|isbn=0774808446|location=Vancouver [B.C.]|oclc=181843232}}</ref> In 1998, he became the head negotiator of the Grand Council of the Crees of Quebec.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> Since 2015, Abel Bosum has also served as President of the Aanischaaukamikw Foundation and of the Aanischaaukamikw Cree Cultural institute.<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=http://creeculturalinstitute.ca/2015/04/23/aanischaaukamikw-welcomes-abel-bosum-as-president/|title=Aanischaaukamikw welcomes Abel Bosum as President|date=2015-04-23|work=Aanischaaukamikw|access-date=2018-04-01|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Early life == Abel Bosum was born the oldest of 11 children of his mother Lucy Busom.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/indigenous/successful-cree-negotiator-finds-the-french-canadian-father-he-never-knew-1.2781824|title=Abel Bosum finds the father he never knew|work=CBC News|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en}}</ref> He was born on an island on Dore Lake in Northern Quebec. <ref name=":1" /> His father, Cypien Caron, was a French-Canadian from Quebec City who had a relationship with Lucy Busom in her settlement near Chibougamau, Quebec.<ref name=":3" /> His mother Lucy was not allowed to marry his father because of the traditional values of their community and so Abel Bosum would not meet his biological father until he was 53 years old.<ref name=":3" /> Abel Bosum's stepfather, Sam Neepoosh, would act as his father figure during his early years until Neepoosh passed away when Abel Bosum was 14 years old in 1969.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":1" />
For 10 years, Abel Bosum attended the La Tuque Residential school in La Tuque, Quebec, run by the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, 150 km north of Trois-Rivières.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.anglican.ca/tr/histories/la-tuque-quebec/|title=La Tuque School — Quebec - Anglican Church of Canada|work=Anglican Church of Canada|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en-US}}</ref> Once Abel Bosum left the school, he worked in underground mines in the [[Chibougamau]] area and also took fishing jobs in order to support his family. <ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
== Career ==
=== Head of economic-development department of the Grand Council of the Crees (Eeyou Istchee) === Abel Bosum studied business administration and began to work for the Grand Council of the Crees (GCC) at age 22 where he was named the head of its economic-development department. He held this position for 6 years. <ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> According to Abel Bosum, while he worked to help other Cree communities with the GCC, he came to the realisation that his own people were in need of support to help ameliorate their living conditions.<ref name=":1" />
=== Chief of the Oujé-Bougoumou === In 1984, at age 28, Abel Bosum became the chief of the [[Oujé-Bougoumou, Quebec|Oujé-Bougoumou]], a position he would hold for 14 years. [[Oujé-Bougoumou, Quebec|Oujé-Bougoumou]] which translates to "the place where the people gather",<ref name=":4" /> is the Cree nation in which Abel Bosum was born. When Abel Bosum became its chief it marked the beginning of a new era for the people.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> Over the preceding half century, they had been struggling to survive as a group and were considered "among the most destitute people of the developed world".<ref name=":6">Finkel, A. (2006). ''Social Policy and Practice in Canada : A History''. Waterloo, Ont: WLU Press. </ref> Between 1926 and 1970, they had been forced to move their settlements seven times because of mineral discoveries that had been made in the region of [[James Bay]], their traditional homeland.<ref name=":5" /> Because of the amount of relocation that the nation had undergone, by the 1970s many of its members were living in tarpaper and plywood shacks along logging roads, without running water or heat, and were split into six family groups. <ref name=":4" /><ref name=":1" /> Others had moved to other Northern Quebec First Nations communities.<ref name=":5" /> In the late 1970s and early 1980s, Abel Bosum had moved to [[Val-d'Or|Val D'Or]], Quebec.<ref name=":4" /> During the period before he became chief and while he worked for the Grand Council of the Quebec Crees, Abel Bosum served as a link among members of the community and its elders.<ref name=":4" /> When meeting and discussing with the Oujé-Bougoumou elders about the nation's situation, they and Abel Bosum decided that they wished to take action.<ref name=":4" /> With Abel Bosum as their leader, they decided to negotiate with the federal and provincial governments to try to rectify the situation of the nation and return it to a community that could flourish. It was under this premise that Abel Bosum became chief of the Oujé-Bougoumou with the goal of negotiating with the Province of Quebec to provide his people with more suitable living conditions and to defend and promote the Oujé-Bougoumou's aboriginal rights in Quebec and Canada.<ref name=":2" />
=== Negotiating on behalf of the Oujé-Bougoumou === There were several challenges that Abel Bosum faced in his negotiations on behalf of the Oujé-Bougoumou nation. One was their omission from the [[James Bay and Northern Quebec Agreement]] made in 1975 that provided compensation to Cree people in the [[James Bay]] region.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":1" /> These stipends from the [[Government of Quebec|Quebec provincial government]] would aid in the development of Cree nations. However due to the mistake of an employee of the Canadian Federal Department of Indian Affairs in 1936, who had falsely combined the [[Oujé-Bougoumou, Quebec|Oujé-Bougoumou]] nation with the [[Mistissini (Cree village municipality)|Mistassini Cree]] nation, one located 90 kilometres away, the Oujé-Bougoumou had no recognised land rights in their traditional territory.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":1" /> Thus, they were excluded from the benefits of the James Bay pact that other Cree nations were able to have. This issue is one that Abel Bosum spent significant time bringing awareness to.
Abel Bosum's negotiation strategy was based on gaining recognition for the [[Oujé-Bougoumou, Quebec|Oujé-Bougoumou]] who had not been able to sufficiently make themselves a priority to provincial and national government so as to effect change for their status.<ref name=":5" /> By having an anthropological study done of his people, Abel Bosum was able to give them a clear and distinct identity with a historical basis. This would legitimise the group and give them a stronger basis for their claim as a people.<ref name=":5" /> Abel Bosum then worked to develop a proposal that would allocate land to his people which he submitted to both the [[Government of Canada|federal government of Canada]] and the provincial government of Quebec. Although at this time the nation itself had no financial resources left, they and Abel Bosum were supported by the Grand Council of the Crees to continue their struggle.<ref name=":5" />
During the negotiations he was leading on behalf of his people, Abel Bosum held many meetings among members of the Oujé-Bougoumou. The meetings had the goal of bringing together the interests of the community members surrounding a common goal and served to help bridge generational differences that existed among its members.<ref name=":5" /> By uniting the Oujé-Bougoumou around a common vision for their future, allowing elders to pass on their knowledge of traditional culture to the younger generations, and discussing the way things had been for the nation before contact with settlers in Northern Quebec due to mining, Abel mobilised the members of the younger generation of the Cree nation who began to pressure the government to act on the issues facing their community.<ref name=":5" /> Furthermore, because of the spread-out locations of the members of Oujé-Bougoumou, Abel Bosum strove to bring together his people even before they obtained their own territory. To do so he established an Oujé-Bougoumou office that organised them into a political action group.<ref name=":5" />
==== Political obstacles ==== When attempting to obtain recognition from the federal and provincial governments, there were additional hurdles that Abel Bosum encountered. Because the Canadian federal government insisted that the Oujé-Bougoumou have a land base in order to be recognised, and the Quebec government, newly under [[Parti Québécois|Parti Quebecois]] leadership in 1976, "strongly opposed the establishment of any new federal lands in Quebec,"<ref name=":5" /> Abel Bosum found his nation at an impasse with the provincial government. However, after bringing a letter to [[René Lévesque|René Levesque]], premier of Quebec, from the federal government stating that the Oujé-Bougoumou would be recognised upon obtaining a land base, and with much negotiation effort on the part of Abel Bosum and the Oujé-Bougoumou Crees, the premier conceded one square mile of territory for an Oujé-Bougoumou village.<ref name=":5" /> With this commitment secured, Abel Bosum returned to the federal government which agreed to begin negotiations to recognise the Oujé-Bougoumou officially.<ref name=":5" />
Abel Bosum's goal was for the Oujé-Bougoumou to become full participants in the treaty that benefited the Cree peoples of Northern Quebec, the James Bay Northern Quebec Agreement (JBNQA).<ref name=":5" /> But, the Quebec government told the Oujé-Bougoumou that they could only settle in an area not already part of a mining claim or part of a forestry concession in the region. This condition limited the options of the Oujé-Bougoumou such that they were not able to find a suitable territory to settle in because they lacked any commercial opportunities for the Oujé-Bougoumou people.<ref name=":5" /> In the early 1980s,the Oujé-Bougoumou traditional territory was occupied by two municipal areas, six mining sites, and the operations of six forestry companies.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|title=The forgotten Crees lauded on world stage (Ouje-Bougoumou)|last=|first=|date=March 31, 1996|work=Catholic New Times|archive-date=June 9, 2010|dead-url=}}</ref> In 1985, after a change in the leadership of the Quebec provincial government to the Quebec liberal party, Abel Bosum tried to negotiate with the new premier, [[Robert Bourassa]]. These negotiations did not last long before an impasse was reached and so Abel Bosum decided to take another approach.<ref name=":5" />
==== Breaking through ==== Abel Bosum then decided to get into contact with someone who had been involved with the original JBNQA negotiations. Member of Provincial Parliament [[John Ciaccia]], had negotiated on behalf of Quebec and was able to inform Abel Bosum of what obstacles needed to be overcome in order to solve the challenge he had been facing to obtain recognised territory for his people.<ref name=":5" /> Abel Bosum was able to reach a verbal agreement with this senior provincial minister to re-negotiate Oujé-Bougoumou land as soon as the Quebec Liberal party came to power.<ref name=":5" />
In his dealings with the Quebec provincial government, Abel Bosum first wished to have his people granted a larger area in which to live by the province than one square mile. He was able to get the Liberal Quebec government to agree to grant his people a territory similar in size to that of other Cree nations in Northern Quebec. <ref name=":5" /> Although at this time, Quebec refused to re-open the JBNQA talks, there were a certain number of Oujé-Bougoumou registered under the [[Mistissini, Quebec|Mistissini]] nation, which was a part of the agreement. Abel's strategy consisted of proposing that Mistissini land be transferred to the Oujé-Bougoumou based on the number of Oujé-Bougoumou among the Mistissini so that the Oujé-Bougoumou could effectively be under the treaty. <ref name=":5" />Abel Bosum then had John Ciaccia amend the JBNQA to effect this change.
Another way that Abel Bosum was able to put pressure on the government was by having the Grand Council of the Crees proclaim that they would not be a signatory party to any agreement unless the Oujé-Bougoumou be also included. <ref name=":5" />Abel Bosum says that he subsequently had "several meetings with the prime minister" of Canada that were able to secure more commitments from the federal government. In 1986, this brought him to the point where he could, with the consultation of his people, select a site where their new village would be developed.<ref name=":5" />
=== Linking the Oujé-Bougoumou's situation to human rights activism === During the time he was negotiating with the Provincial and Federal governments to improve the situation of his people, Abel Bosum concurrently had to deal with the social issues that his community faced living in makeshift settlements along remote highways. Abel Bosum referred to their condition as an "urgent" one and worked to instill temporary measures to safeguard the health and well-being of the Oujé-Bougoumou while a new area of settlement was being negotiated.<ref name=":5" /> For example, Abel Bosum was able to "get some funding" to install trailers with washrooms and running water in the six main encampments at which his people resided.<ref name=":5" />
In order to apply pressure on the government, Abel Bosum also involved the media and his own people to document the conditions that the Oujé-Bougoumou were living in and expose their situation to the public. Through the media coverage they received, the Oujé-Bougoumou were also able "to attend various conferences dealing with human rights and housing where they could bring awareness surrounding their struggles."<ref name=":5" /> By informing the public of his people's situation, and emphasizing the human rights violations they were encountering within a first world country, Abel Bosum successfully put more pressure on the provincial and federal governments to change the situation of the Oujé-Bougoumou and negotiations re-started with more commitment on their part.<ref name=":5" />
=== Civil disobedience === The federal government began to make preliminary offers to Abel Bosum and the Oujé-Bougoumou to finance their new settlement however these offers were lower than the nation thought it needed to adequately address the needs of the community.<ref name=":5" /> The federal government decided to provide a maximum of $14 million CAD to the Oujé-Bougoumou to begin their new village, but after much internal discussion and consultation with the elders, and despite the risk that they might not get another offer as other [[First Nations|first nations]] had not gotten after refusing a government offer, Abel Bosum refused the offer on behalf of the Oujé-Bougoumou.<ref name=":5" />
After a year of silence from the government on the issue, the Oujé-Bougoumou were looking to apply pressure by whatever means they could on the government to get a larger financial commitment from it for the construction of their village.<ref name=":5" /> First, Abel Bosum encouraged his people to occupy the site that they had chosen for their home without a final agreement granting them the territory. Energy Resources Quebec opposed this strategy and demanded that they stop building on the land.<ref name=":5" /> However, the Cree disobeyed and made camps as they left their former makeshift ones by the sides of the roads.<ref name=":5" /> Second, with more young Cree getting involved, discussions began surrounding blockades and other acts of civil disobedience. For maximum impact, Abel Bosum and the Oujé-Bougoumou decided to block a nearby forestry road that also served as an access road to mining sites and to a popular recreational fishing location, the Assinica river.<ref name=":5" /> This strategy affected the commerce in the area significantly as it obstructed activities of three resource sectors and "created a lot of tension for the region."<ref name=":5" />
=== A final agreement ===
With the pressure put on the government based on the disruptive civil disobedience practiced by the Oujé-Bougoumou in Northern Quebec, real strides were made to reach a final agreement for the village in which this nation could permanently reside. Abel Bosum was contacted by the Liberal provincial minister of natural resources for Quebec, Raymond Savoie who wished to meet with him to develop a comprehensive agreement that would put an end to the grievances of the Oujé-Bougoumou.<ref name=":5" /> At the meeting was a delegation of 15 members from Quebec as well as one negotiator from the Canadian government who had come to speak with Abel Bosum. In discussions that went late into the night and early into the morning, the governments agreed in principle to support the construction of the Oujé-Bougoumou village and "to provide a social and economic development fund" that would serve to keep the Oujé-Bougoumou people employed and allow them to develop their own economic opportunities in the future.<ref name=":5" /> However, the federal government later backed out of the agreement because it did not agree with the principle of a social and economic development fund. Because the province of Quebec felt more pressure from the civil disobedience of the Oujé-Bougoumou to make a deal with them, Abel Bosum continued to negotiate solely with the province.<ref name=":5" /> Finally he was able to obtain a deal granting the Oujé-Bougoumou financial support for the infrastructure of their village and a $20 million contribution towards social and economic development for the nation as well as 167 square kilometers of land.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":5" /> He then sought to use this agreement to put leverage on the federal government to gain their contribution for the village's success. Making use as he had earlier of information politics, this time in the form of a media campaign, so that dialogue might continue with the federal government, Abel Bosum pressured them to put a new negotiator in place to deal with the Oujé-Bougoumou and other Cree issues.<ref name=":5" /> By the late 1980s and early 1990s, the Oujé-Bougoumou's struggle had become a symbolic one for aboriginal rights issues in Canada.
In 1992, Abel Bosum and Oujé-Bougoumou signed a deal that brought them $43.6 million from the federal government towards the construction of their village. <ref name=":1" /> Though this deal, according to Abel Bosum, "'did not include everything we wanted,"<ref name=":5" /> it was considered by him to be a good enough one to justify signing especially given the pressing needs of the members of the Oujé-Bougoumou who did not have homes.
=== The Oujé-Bougoumou village === The village that Abel Bosum is credited with founding is located Lake Opemisca, Quebec.<ref name=":4" /> Built in consultation with the Oujé-Bougoumou people, it is home to 750 Cree and has been recognised by the United Nations as one of 50 model communities worldwide.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7">Peritz, I. (2005, Nov 26). In cree village, there's no place like home. ''The Globe and Mail'' Retrieved from <nowiki>http://www.ubishops.ca:2048/docview/383610220?accountid=8636</nowiki> </ref> It gained this recognition because it was able to fulfill needs of the community while also being an environmentally sustainable and technologically advanced settlement.<ref name=":4" /> Although it is located in a remote area of Northern Quebec, its inhabitants have a low level of unemployment and new houses are continuing to be built to meet the demand of young Cree people who wish to gain ownership of their own home.<ref name=":7" /> The village is considered to be a unique one in Canada as it provides excellent living conditions in modern houses to Indigenous peoples. The design of the village is one that seeks to reflect the "values and culture of the Oujé-Bougoumou people."<ref name=":6" />
== Later career ==
=== Work in his village as chief ===
After securing the deal to finance his village with the Quebec and Canadian governments, Abel Bosum as chief of the Oujé-Bougoumou worked to facilitate the social and economic development for his people in their new home. This involved securing access to essential natural resources so that his community could be financially self-sustaining as well as tackling social issues that his people had developed mainly due to the instability of their dwellings.<ref name=":5" /> For example at a certain point, "over 90 per cent of Oujé-Bougoumou adults had alcohol problems, and that has fallen below 50 per cent."<ref name=":4" /> Abel Bosum's main goal for his village however was for it to prove that aboriginal groups in Canada can make good use of the resources provided to them by the government and that these communities can exist in an politically and economically independent state.<ref name=":5" />
=== Negotiating for all Crees: Quebec negotiator for the Grand Council of the Crees (Eeyou Istchee) ===
Based on his work in advocating for his own nation's rights with the government of Quebec, in 1998, Abel Bosum was chosen to negotiate on behalf of all the Crees of Quebec as the GCC Quebec negotiator.<ref name=":2" /> In the year 2000, he was able "to break a two-year-long impasse between the Crees and Quebec."<ref name=":1" /> In the summer of 2000, he began negotiating with Quebec on the 1975 James Bay agreement, eventually reaching a new agreement for governing the James Bay region with the Quebec government in 2012.
In 2002, Abel Bosum led the negotiations of the [[Agreement Respecting a New Relationship Between the Cree Nation and the Government of Quebec|Agreement Respecting a New Relationships Between the Cree Nation and the Government of Quebec]] (La Paix des Braves) signed on February 7th, 2002, between the Government of Quebec and the Grand Council of the Crees (GCC). This agreement serves to better integrate the Crees into the economic activities that go on in their region, shares the revenues from them with Quebec Crees, and also allows them to make decisions pertaining to their own development with the funds they receive from the provincial government.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gcc.ca/issues/paixdesbraves.php|title=The Grand Council of the Crees (Eeyou Istchee) > Critical Issues >|website=www.gcc.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-03-12}}</ref>
Abel Bosum has worked to negotiate on behalf of the Cree Board of Health and Social Services of James Bay in order to obtain health and social services for Cree people. He has also negotiated for the Cree School Board and represented the GCC in discussions with neighbouring aboriginal nations.<ref name=":2" />
Furthermore, he has negotiated on behalf of the GCC and several individual Cree communities "with five mining companies to ensure financial benefits, employment and environmental protection measures" be provided to Cree people in the areas where mining activities are conducted.<ref name=":2" />
Finally, in 2012, he negotiated the James Bay Governance Agreement that would change the way the region is administered by giving "Cree jurisdiction over the traditional Cree territory."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/quebecam/2012/07/25/a-new-model-for-governing/|title=Historic agreement with the James Bay Cree|last=|first=|date=|website=www.cbc.ca|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-12}}</ref><ref name=":2" /> The agreement also developed new Cree governance structures.
=== Charitable work ===
Abel Bosum was chosen as president of the Aanischaaukamikw Foundation and Cree Cultural Institute on April 2nd, 2015.<ref name=":8" /> Abel Bosum has helped to raise $25.6 million to develop the institute. The foundation is a registered charitable organisation, is not-for-profit, and obtained the funding it required to build the cultural institute from "Cree and non-Cree governments, corporate partners, private foundations and individuals."<ref name=":2" />
=== Grand Chief of the Grand Council of the Crees (Eeyou Istchee) ===
Abel Bosum was elected for a four-year term as Grand Chief of the Council of the Crees of Northern Quebec on July 24th, 2017 with 55.9% of the vote share. He defeated the outgoing Deputy Grand Chief Rodney Mark. He succeeded Grand Chief [[Matthew Coon Come]] who had previously served five-terms as Grand Chief over a 40-year period.<ref name=":0" />
As Grand Chief he has overseen the adoption of Bill C-70 into law by the Canadian government. The bill provides the Eeyou Istchee with a higher degree of political self-determination as it allows the GCC to "create its own culturally relevant laws and have more say on a variety of local governance issues, including development."<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=https://senate-gro.ca/new-laws/c-70-cree-naskapi/|title=More self-determination for two northern Quebec First Nations|work=Senate GRO|access-date=2018-04-01|language=en-US}}</ref> The bill is an extension of the rights provided in the 1975 James Bay and Northern Quebec Agreement. According to Abel Bosum, as expressed in his address to the Standing Senate Committee on Aboriginal Peoples, it as an important step to advancing towards full Cree self-governance.<ref name=":9" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gcc.ca/newsarticle.php?id=491|title=The Grand Council of the Crees (Eeyou Istchee) > Statement By Grand Chief Dr. Abel Bosum To The Standing Senate Committee On Aboriginal Peoples On Bill C-70, Cree Nation Of Eeyou Istchee Governance Agreement Act|website=gcc.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-04-01}}</ref>
== Recognition == In 1998, Abel Bosum received Canada's National Aboriginal Achievement Award in the category of Community Development for his work with the Oujé-Bougoumou Cree community.<ref name=":2" />
In June of 2016, Abel Bosum received the degree of Doctor of Civil Law, Honoris Causa, from [[Bishop's University]] in Sherbrooke, Quebec.<ref name=":2" /> And, in 2018, he was appointed to the [[Order of Canada]], an honour recognising "outstanding achievement, dedication to the community and service to the nation."<ref>Governor General Updates on 125 New Appointments to the Order of Canada. (2018, January 7). ''Entertainment Close-up''. Retrieved from <nowiki>http://link.galegroup.com/apps/doc/A521701669/ITOF?u=crepuq_bishop&sid=ITOF&xid=8eec7083</nowiki></ref>

'''Adrián Nicolás Guida''' ([[Buenos Aires]], 26 March 1965 - 12 December 1994) was an [[Argentina|Argentine]] [[tango music|tango]] musician. His works at [[Osvaldo Pugliese]]'s Orchestra were notable, including songs 'Contame una historia', 'Bailemos' and 'Milonga para [[Carlos Gardel|Gardel]]', featuring [[Abel Córdoba]]. He died from [[pulmonary edema]] in 1994.

<!--Per Wikipedia:Manual of style, use she/her to refer to Alexandra Billings throughout her life.--> {{Infobox person | name = Alexandra Billings | image = Alexandra Billings.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|3|28}} | birth_place = [[Schaumburg, Illinois|Schaumburg]], [[Illinois]], U.S. | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | known_for = Second openly transgender woman to have played a transgender character on television | occupation = Actress, [[Model (person)|model]] | partner = {{marriage|Chrisanne Blankenship|December 4, 1995}} }}
'''Alexandra Scott Billings''' (born March 28, 1962) is an [[United states|American]] [[actress]], teacher, singer, and activist. Billings is among the first openly [[transgender]] women to have played a transgender character on television, which she did in the 2005 made-for-TV movie ''Romy and Michele: In The Beginning''. She is also known for portraying the recurring character Davina in the Amazon series ''[[Transparent (TV series)|Transparent]]'' and has played transgender characters in ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', ''[[Eli Stone]]'', ''[[How to Get Away with Murder]]'' and ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]''.<ref name="the Guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2014/oct/10/-sp-alexandra-billings-transgender-actor-transparent|title=Alexandra Billings, transgender actor: 'Transparent came up when I had nothing to lose'|work=the Guardian}}</ref><ref name=sftimes>{{cite web |title=A Twisted Sister |url=http://www.sfbaytimes.com/index.php?sec=article&article_id=7145 |work=[[San Francisco Bay Times]] |first=Jacob |last=Anderson-Minshall |date=13 December 2007 |accessdate=14 December 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101212201355/http://www.sfbaytimes.com/index.php?sec=article&article_id=7145| archivedate= 12 December 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
== Early life == Billings' father, Robert Billings, was a music teacher at [[Los Angeles Harbor College]] and the musical director for the [[Los Angeles Civic Light Opera]], which influenced her interest in theater.<ref name=billings>{{cite web |title=ALEXANDRA BILLINGS Consummate Actor and Cabaret Singer |url=http://www.alexandrabillings.com/site/billings.html |work=AlexandraBillings.com |accessdate=14 December 2010}}</ref> She assisted, working backstage with [[Carol Burnett]] and [[Yul Brynner]]. She also appeared in ''[[Jesus Christ Superstar]]'' and ''[[The Roar of the Greasepaint—the Smell of the Crowd]]''. In her early life, Billings struggled with homelessness, prostitution, and cocaine and opioid addiction.<ref name="Human Rights Campaign">{{Citation|last=Human Rights Campaign|title=Alexandra Billings Receives the HRC Visibility Award|date=2016-10-03|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U3bshgCXFwg|accessdate=2017-12-04}}</ref>
== Career == In the early 1980s, Billings worked under the stage name Shante at the famed [[Baton Show Lounge]] in Chicago, Illinois.<ref name=chicagopride>{{cite web|url=http://chicago.gopride.com/news/article.cfm/articleid/7482961 |title=Alexandra Billings named Grand Marshal for Chicago Pride Parade |date=30 May 2009 |accessdate=14 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111018122626/http://chicago.gopride.com/news/article.cfm/articleid/7482961 |archivedate=18 October 2011 }}</ref> Winning a series of beauty contests, she was named Miss Wisconsin, Miss New York, Miss Chicago, Miss Illinois, and Miss Florida. She also served as a judge of the [[Miss Continental]] pageant in 2000 and 2001.
Most of Billings' professional work has been in Chicago theaters, most notably [[The Bailiwick Theater]], [[Light Opera Works]], [[Court Theatre (Chicago)|Court Theatre]], and [[Steppenwolf Theatre]]. She has collaborated on plays with such notable authors as [[Larry Kramer]], [[Tina Landau]], and [[Jamie Pachino]]. She has received one [[Joseph Jefferson Award]] and five [[After Dark Awards]] for her work in [[Chicago Theater]]. Her one-person autobiographical show has toured to Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles and off Broadway. She is a former artistic associate of [[About Face Theatre]].
More recently, Billings has appeared in an autobiographical show, "S/He and Me." <ref>https://web.csulb.edu/colleges/cota/theatre/documents/ShowDocuments/15-16/S-He&MePlaybill.pdf</ref> In fall 2018, she also appeared in [[The Nap]] at [[Manhattan Theatre Club]], and is one of the first openly trans people (if not the first) to be cast in a trans role on Broadway.<ref>http://www.playbill.com/production/the-nap-samuel-j-friedman-theatre-2018-2019</ref>
In the early 2000s, [[WTTW]], the PBS station in Chicago, produced a documentary about Billings' life and career, "Schoolboy to Showgirl: The Alexandra Billings Story." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://video.wttw.com/video/2365891768/ |title=Video: Schoolboy to Showgirl: The Alexandra Billings Story | Watch WTTW Documentaries Online | WTTW11 Video |publisher=Video.wttw.com |date= |accessdate=2017-06-21}}</ref>
She has taught Viewpoints at the Steppenwolf Summer School since 2002 as well as taught at Louis University, [[The University of Chicago]], Illinois University,the Illinois Theatre Convention, Act One Studios, and various classes and workshops around the Chicago area. Currently, she teaches at the Steppenwolf School West in Los Angeles California. Billings is currently a professor at the [[University of Southern California]] in Los Angeles, California where she is a Theatre professor. Before working at USC, she was an assistant professor at California State University, Long Beach.<ref name="news.usc.edu">{{Cite news|url=https://news.usc.edu/128301/alexandra-billings-of-transparent-talks-transitioning-teaching-and-life-experiences/|title=Alexandra Billings of Transparent talks transitioning, teaching and life experiences|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-US}}</ref> She received her MFA from CSULB, and delivered the commencement speech for CSULB College of the Arts in 2015.<ref>{{Citation|last=csulbwebteam|title=Alexandra Billings CSULB College of the Arts Commencement Speech 2015|date=2015-06-04|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hfOsS1CA0HY|accessdate=2017-12-04}}</ref>
Billings is also a professional singer who performs in theaters and nightclubs throughout the United States. She recorded her second CD ''The Story Goes On'' in 2003. She was a recipient of the New York MAC Hanson Award for Cabaret Artist of the Year in 2004.
In 2010, Billings appeared in the film ''[[FAUX]]'', in which she commented on gay marriage spurring the economy.<ref>{{cite news|last=Townsend|first=John|title=Transgender Television Groundbreaker Plays the Loring|url=http://www.lavendermagazine.com/archives/issue-418/transgender-television-groundbreaker-plays-the-loring/|accessdate=21 August 2011|newspaper=Lavender|date=June 17, 2011}}</ref>
In 2017, transgender actors and actresses, including Billings (with the help of [[GLAAD]] and [[ScreenCrush]]), were part of a film to Hollywood written by [[Jen Richards]], asking for more and improved roles for transgender people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/transgender-hollywood-video_us_594964b8e4b08709c82fe34c |title=New Video Breaks Down Why Hollywood Needs Transgender Actors | HuffPost |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date=2017 |accessdate=2017-06-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Reynolds |first=Daniel |url=https://www.advocate.com/transgender/2017/6/20/trans-actors-ask-hollywood-roles-dignity-and-depth-open-letter |title=Trans Actors Ask Hollywood for Roles with Dignity and Depth in Open Letter |publisher=Advocate.com |date= |accessdate=2017-06-21}}</ref>
=== Television appearances === She has appeared in the 2005 made-for-TV movie ''Romy and Michelle: A New Beginning''. She has also played transgender characters in episodes of ''[[Karen Sisco]]'', ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', ''[[Eli Stone]]'', ''[[How to Get Away with Murder]]'' and ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]''.<ref name="the Guardian"/>
In 2015, Billings appeared on season two, episode six of ''[[How to Get Away with Murder]]'' as Professor Jill Hartford.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/AlexSBillings/status/659503778903650304 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-10-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306022123/https://twitter.com/AlexSBillings/status/659503778903650304 |archivedate=2016-03-06 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=29 Oct 2015 |url=https://twitter.com/petenowalk/status/659916828437712896 |title=Pete Nowalk on Twitter: "Thank you @AlexSBillings aka Jill for coming and playing with us #HTGAWM" |publisher=Twitter.com |date=2015-10-29 |accessdate=2017-06-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvfanatic.com/2015/10/how-to-get-away-with-murder-season-2-episode-6-review-two-birds/#comment-2334322093 |title=How to Get Away with Murder Season 2 Episode 6 Review: Two Birds, One Millstone |publisher=TV Fanatic |date= |accessdate=2017-06-21}}</ref>
In 2018, Billings plays Judge Martha Wallace in the second season of ''[[Goliath (TV series)|Goliath]]''.
Billings may be best known for her role as Davina in the Amazon series ''[[Transparent (TV series)|Transparent]]''. The character was introduced in an early episode of season one and has appeared in subsequent seasons.
== Activism == Alexandra Billings is an [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]] and [[LGBT|LGBTQ]] activist who argues for the equality of the LGBTQ community and urges others to use their voices to create change within the LGBTQ community.<ref name="news.usc.edu"/> In 2016, Billings was awarded the [[Human Rights Campaign]] Visibility Award, which recognizes outstanding members of the LGBTQ community who live openly and freely in the public eye. After receiving the award, Billings thanked the audience, but also said, “I look around and I see you all and I cannot tell you how grateful I am that you’re here, and I have to say something to you I think you look great, you look swell and it’s wonderful that you’re here eating the chicken it’s delightful but I must tell you that we have to do something more than sit and speak and talk to our neighbors and eat great food and put on fancy clothes.” She challenges the audience to use their voices to speak loudly in order to create change and ultimately, equality for the LGBTQ community. In 2017, [[Transparent (TV series)|Transparent]], the hit TV show Billings stars in, won the [[GLAAD]] Media Award for Outstanding Comedy Series. When accepting the award on behalf of the cast, Billings urges the audience to talk to people who disagree with their beliefs in order to spark conversation and create change instead of staying complacent. Specifically, she calls out the older LGBTQ generation and asks them to guide the younger LGBTQ generation because they will be the ones continuing the fight for equality in the future.<ref>{{Citation|last=GLAAD|title=Alexandra Billings Calls for Unity l 28th Annual GLAAD Media Awards|date=2017-04-07|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K1f5hrH-CdU|accessdate=2017-12-04}}</ref> When delivering the commencement speech to the graduating class of the University of California State, Long Beach in 2015, Billings once again emphasized the importance of voice when she told the students that it is their job is to speak loud, big, and wide in order to spread their voices.<ref>{{Citation|last=csulbwebteam|title=Alexandra Billings CSULB College of the Arts Commencement Speech 2015|date=2015-06-04|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hfOsS1CA0HY|accessdate=2017-12-04}}</ref>
== Personal life ==
Billings lives in [[Hollywood]], [[California]] with her wife Chrisanne, whom she initially met at age sixteen in drama class.<ref>{{Citation|last=csulbwebteam|title=Alexandra Billings CSULB College of the Arts Commencement Speech 2015|date=2015-06-04|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hfOsS1CA0HY|accessdate=2017-12-04}}</ref> They were married in a commitment ceremony in Chicago on December 4, 1995.<ref name=chicagopride /> Billings was chosen as the Grand Marshal for the Pride Parade in Chicago, Illinois on June 28, 2009.
Billings has been living with HIV since 1994, and has been an advocate for HIV health initiatives, as well as trans issues and trans rights. When talking about her fight to battle AIDS, she says that she believes the reason she has survived all these years is because of her wife who stood by her, loved her, and supported her through it all.<ref name="Human Rights Campaign"/> She has spoken about her status in a number of interviews, including a 2016 article with her hometown paper.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20160216/entlife/160219215/ |title='Transparent' transgender actress bullied growing up in Schaumburg |publisher=Dailyherald.com |date=2016-02-16 |accessdate=2017-06-21}}</ref> She also spoke to POZ Magazine for a 2003 interview about life with HIV.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.poz.com/article/Star-Billings-616-5876 |title=Star Billings |publisher=POZ |date=2003-05-01 |accessdate=2017-06-21}}</ref>

= dmy-all}} In late March 2015, shortly after the death of the first [[Prime Minister of Singapore]], [[Lee Kuan Yew]], Yee uploaded a video on YouTube criticising Lee. In the video, Yee compared Lee to [[Jesus]], and cast both in an unfavourable light. Yee also uploaded to his blog an image depicting Lee and [[Margaret Thatcher]] engaged in [[anal sex]]. Yee was arrested and charged with "intention of wounding the religious feelings of [[Christians]]", obscenity, and "threatening, abusive or insulting communication." The first two charges fall under the [[Penal Code (Singapore)|Singapore Penal Code]]. The third charge, which was later withdrawn, was a response to the video's criticism of Lee and falls under the [[Protection from Harassment Act (Singapore)|Protection from Harassment Act]] (POHA). Yee's trial, which took place on 7 to 8 May 2015, attracted much public interest.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee pleads not guilty to both charges|url = guilty on 12 May 2015,{{cite web|title = Teenage blogger Amos Yee out on bail|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/courts-crime/story/teenage-blogger-amos-yee-out-bail-20150512|website = ''The New Paper'' described Yee as having taken on four different acting roles in his "self-written, self-directed film", which was described as a "twisted dark comedy" in which a boy tries to persuade his three friends to help a cancer-stricken girl.{{cite web|title=Youths gone mild|url=http://newshub.nus.edu.sg/news/1201/PDF/YOUTHS-tnp-12jan-p22.pdf|website=[[The New Paper]]|accessdate=3 April 2015|date=12 January 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403013242/http://newshub.nus.edu.sg/news/1201/PDF/YOUTHS-tnp-12jan-p22.pdf|archive-date=3 April 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|last1=Soh|first1=Joanne|title=FiRST Film Fest is back!|url=http://www2.tnp.sg/fff2/content/first-film-fest-back|website=[[The New Paper]]|accessdate=5 May 2015|date=1 December 2011|location=Singapore|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518075535/http://www2.tnp.sg/fff2/content/first-film-fest-back#|archive-date=18 May 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Yee, thirteen at the time, was described as having made the film "in his bedroom". The FFF awarded Yee a [[Sony Handycam NEX-VG10]] video camera and [[Sony Vegas Movie Studio]] HD Platinum 10 [[video editing software]]. Following the success of ''Jan'', FFF chief judge [[Jack Neo]] offered an [[internship]] to Yee, and additionally invited Yee to [[audition]] for Neo's film, ''[[We Not Naughty]]'', a film about [[juvenile delinquency]]. When Yee did so in May 2011, Neo cast Yee in a minor acting role after Yee improvised and improved the language in a script given to him. Yee played a "smart younger brother" to a lead actor's character, and was allowed by Neo to write his own dialogue. Neo said that while Yee only had three scenes in the movie, they were "crucial".{{cite news |last1=Chua |first1=Charlene |title=Teen actor flamed for video dissing CNY (page 2) |url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest%2BNews/Showbiz/Story/A1Story20120120-323071/2.html |work=[[The New Paper]] |location=Singapore |accessdate=1 April 2015 |date=22 January 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150401020158/http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest+News/Showbiz/Story/A1Story20120120-323071/2.html |archive-date=1 April 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Neo also praised Yee as a "natural comedian" with a passion for film-making. Regarding Yee being labelled as arrogant, Neo said that "just because [Yee] acts arrogant doesn't mean he is ... He is an actor, he's playing a role". Yet, Neo also suggested that Yee needed to learn humility. {{Quote box|width=30%|align=right|quote="He has been making videos for a long time and I have already had a few talks with him because he's very open with his views. Yee was also introduced to [[Roy Ngerng]]'s blog by an SDP member, and Yee said he was convinced by what Ngerng had published. ===Initial reaction=== ''The Straits Times'' reported that Yee "was largely slammed by netizens over the video, although some defended his right to his opinion", whilst the BBC News reported that the video drew a "visceral response from Singaporeans". The 2015 video resulted in several violent and threatening remarks being made against Yee online, including rape threats,{{cite news|title = Singapore mom of detained teen Amos Yee: 'Sorry, son' - CNN.com|url = http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/30/asia/singapore-amos-yee-mother-sorry/index.html|website = CNN|accessdate = 7 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150708025513/http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/30/asia/singapore-amos-yee-mother-sorry/index.html|archive-date = 8 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} which led to calls by the Media Literacy Council and the [[Singapore Kindness Movement]] urging netizens to act responsibly and civilly, even when facing views they find offensive.{{cite web|author1=Nur Asyiqin Mohamad Salleh|title=Singapore Kindness Movement urges people to be civil when disagreeing with views online|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/more-singapore-stories/story/singapore-kindness-movement-urges-people-be-civil-when-d|website=The Straits Times|accessdate=26 April 2015|date=24 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150425214945/http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/more-singapore-stories/story/singapore-kindness-movement-urges-people-be-civil-when-d|archive-date=25 April 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Singaporean actors [[Gurmit Singh]] and [[Quan Yi Fong]], who both have teenage children, weighed in on the issue. The first charge was that Yee's 2015 video violated Section 298 of the [[Penal Code]], Chapter 224, as it "contained remarks against Christianity, with the deliberate intention of wounding the religious feelings of Christians in general". The second charge was under Section 4 of the Protection from Harassment Act (later withdrawn){{cite web|title=Assault on Amos Yee draws sharp criticism|last1=Lim|first1=Yvonne|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/amos-yee-back-jail-after-no-one-posts-bail-him?singlepage=true|website=[[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]]|accessdate=30 April 2015|date=30 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150503205141/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/amos-yee-back-jail-after-no-one-posts-bail-him?singlepage=true|archive-date=3 May 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} was that Yee's 2015 video violated the [[Protection from Harassment Act 2014]] as it "contained remarks about Mr Lee Kuan Yew which was intended to be heard and seen by persons likely to be distressed". On 3 April, Yee's mother brought him to the [[Institute of Mental Health (Singapore)|Institute of Mental Health]] (IMH) to see a [[psychiatrist]] to understand why he seemed "too daring" and feared nothing,{{cite web|title = Amos Yee's bid to vary bail conditions rejected|url = http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/high-court-dismisses-bid-vary-amos-yees-bail-conditions?page=1|accessdate = 16 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150509174505/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/high-court-dismisses-bid-vary-amos-yees-bail-conditions?page=1|archive-date = 9 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} but Yee quit after two sessions. [[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]] reported that this was because Amos refused to continue the sessions at IMH, but this was contradicted by former bailor Vincent Law, who later told [[The Online Citizen]] that Yee could not attend the third IMH session because it had clashed with the day of his bail review hearing, and that Yee had unsuccessfully asked the institute to bring the session forward.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee pleads not guilty, in good spirits|url = http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/05/amos-yee-pleads-not-guilty-in-good-spirits/|accessdate = 16 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150518105117/http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/05/amos-yee-pleads-not-guilty-in-good-spirits/|archive-date = 18 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} On 14 April Yee flouted his initial bail conditions by asking for [[crowdfunding|public donations to fund his legal fees]] on both on his blog and Facebook page;{{cite web|last1=Spykerman|first1=Kimberly|title=Amos Yee to spend at least one night in remand after parents refuse to post bail|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/amos-yee-likely-spend-weekend-remand|website=[[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]]|accessdate=20 April 2015|date=18 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150421092651/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/amos-yee-likely-spend-weekend-remand|archive-date=21 April 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|last1=Ng|first1=Scott|title=Amos Yee reaches out for help|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/04/15/amos-yee-reaches-out-for-help/|website=[[Free Malaysia Today]]|accessdate=17 April 2015|date=15 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150416213005/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/04/15/amos-yee-reaches-out-for-help/#|archive-date=16 April 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} the blog post also linked to his controversial 2015 video and image. Three lawyers, Alfred Dodwell, Chong Jia Hao and Ervin Tan, also volunteered to represent him ''[[pro bono]]''. On 29 April Yee breached his bail conditions on not uploading content online again by making two blog posts; the first questioned "the ridiculous terms of [his] bail", which Yee said "has absolutely nothing to do with my presence in court". In the second, he accused his father of being "abusive" and violent.{{cite web|title=Amos Yee posts on blog, breaches bail terms|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/amos-yee-posts-blog-breaches-bail-terms|website=[[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]]|accessdate=30 April 2015|date=30 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150503201940/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/amos-yee-posts-blog-breaches-bail-terms|archive-date=3 May 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} On 30 April, the charge concerning remarks against Lee Kuan Yew was stood down. This means that the charge, instead of being dropped, would be dealt with at a later time, after the previous two charges are addressed.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee assaulted on way to court, now in remand|url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-struck-on-way-to/1816460.html|accessdate = 16 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150518074350/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-struck-on-way-to/1816460.html|archive-date = 18 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Yee also refused to take down the two blog posts despite being asked to by the District Judge Kessler Soh, as he felt that taking down the posts in question was tantamount to an admission of guilt. Concurrently, the bail amount was raised to $30,000. Meanwhile, Law applied to discharge himself as Yee's bailor. It remains to be decided whether Law will have to forfeit the previous $20,000 posted. Yee was again taken into remand because of a lack of anyone posting bail. Law later told ''The Online Citizen'' that while he wanted to post bail for Yee again, Yee rejected Law's offer as he did not want himself to be gagged, leading to Law discharging himself. Law also said that he did not regret acting as Yee's bailor, and that from talking to Yee, he had found him to be childlike and lacking in empathy.{{cite web|url=http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/05/vincent-law-no-regrets-as-bailor-for-amos-yee|title=Vincent Law: No regrets as bailor for Amos Yee|last1=Xu|first1=Terry|website=[[The Online Citizen]]|accessdate=6 May 2015|date=5 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530233330/http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/05/vincent-law-no-regrets-as-bailor-for-amos-yee/|archive-date=30 May 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} On 6 May Yee's lawyers appealed for a change in bail amount and bail conditions, arguing that accessing social media was "like drinking water" to Yee, and that the ban on Yee posting online content was "too broad and disproportionate". The prosecution was willing to lower the bail amount and release Yee from having to report daily to a police station if Yee went for psychiatric counselling, but Yee refused. Consequently, the High Court judge [[Tay Yong Kwang]] decided to maintain Yee's bail conditions.{{cite web|last1=Neo|first1=Chai Chin|title=High Court dismisses bid to vary Amos Yee's bail conditions|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/high-court-dismisses-bid-vary-amos-yees-bail-conditions?singlepage=true|website=[[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]]|accessdate=6 May 2015|date=6 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150509212340/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/high-court-dismisses-bid-vary-amos-yees-bail-conditions?singlepage=true|archive-date=9 May 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|last1=Law|first1=Elizabeth|title=No change for Amos Yee's bail conditions|url=http://www.tnp.sg/news/singapore-news/no-change-amos-yees-bail-conditions|website=[[The New Paper]]|accessdate=6 May 2015|date=6 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518072242/http://www.tnp.sg/news/singapore-news/no-change-amos-yees-bail-conditions|archive-date=18 May 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} === Trial === Yee was tried as an adult{{cite web|title = Amos Yee: Singapore charges teen over anti-Lee Kuan Yew rant – BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-32115052|accessdate = 16 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150427092854/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-32115052|archive-date = 27 April 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} on 7–8 May 2015, with Yee pleading not guilty to both charges. The timeline was pushed for by Yee's lawyers so that Yee would not "spend more time in remand than necessary". The case has attracted much public interest, with more than 20 people seen outside Court 7 more than an hour before the hearing was supposed to start.{{cite web|title = Verdict in blogger Amos Yee's trial due Tuesday|url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/blogger-amos-yee-s-trial/1833616.html|accessdate = 16 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150518100053/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/blogger-amos-yee-s-trial/1833616.html|archive-date = 18 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} When Yee was led into the courtroom in handcuffs and leg shackles, several members of the public who were present waved at him, and he smiled at them.{{cite web|title = Defence, prosecution cross swords over Amos Yee's primary intention|url = http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/day-2-amos-yee-trial|accessdate = 16 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150510235311/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/day-2-amos-yee-trial|archive-date = 10 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Amongst those who attended the trial were both of Yee's parents, Yee's former bailor, Vincent Law, blogger [[Roy Ngerng]], as well as social activists Andrew Loh and [[Teo Soh Lung]]. Law, who said he never changed his mind about bailing him out, said that he came to support Yee and hopes he gets a good trial.{{cite web|title = Blogger Amos Yee pleads not guilty to both charges|url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/blogger-amos-yee-s-trial/1830694.html|accessdate = 16 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150518081358/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/blogger-amos-yee-s-trial/1830694.html|archive-date = 18 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}}{{cite web|title = Teen blogger Amos Yee pleads not guilty to both charges at start of two-day trial|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/courts-crime/story/teen-blogger-amos-yees-two-day-trial-begins-20150507|website = Straits Times|accessdate = 16 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150519080403/http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/courts-crime/story/teen-blogger-amos-yees-two-day-trial-begins-20150507|archive-date = 19 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} The prosecution comprises DPPs Hay Hung Chun, Hon Yi and Kelvin Kow. The Defence comprises Alfred Dodwell and Chong Jia Hao from Dodwell & Co LLC and Ervin Tan from Michael Hwang Chambers LLC. The proceedings were presided over by District Judge Jasvendar Kaur. The proceedings began with arguments from the defence regarding the obscenity charge. They argued that the legal test to determine whether or not an image is obscene is whether "it has an effect which is to tend to deprave and corrupt" any person who is exposed to it, and that the prosecution has not provided any evidence that the image passes the test. They argued that Section 292, under which Amos Yee is being charged, "is targeted at peddlers and purveyors of pornography" and that it is "wholly inapt to describe the mischief (if any) in this case". The prosecution had argued that Yee's own comments showed his intention to "corrupt and deprave", but the defence countered that a person cannot be convicted [[ipse dixit]]. They also argued that the image was "not a pornographic image, designed to arouse".{{cite web|url=http://www.dodwell-law.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Amos-Yee-8-May-15-Prosecution-Closing-Submissions.pdf|title=Public prosecutor v Amos Yee Pang Sang|access-date=8 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180824140534/https://www.dodwell-law.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Amos-Yee-8-May-15-Prosecution-Closing-Submissions.pdf|archive-date=24 August 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In court documents, Yee explained that his intention in critiquing both Christianity and Lee Kuan Yew was to open discussions on what he saw as "problems" with the faith and Singapore. He said that he was aware his critique would lead some people to take offence, but argued that this promoted discussion that "was healthy for positive change to take place in future." Yee also explained that while he "was aware that critiquing these problems (with the Christian faith) would promote ill-will", he saw this as "a natural consequence", and that "promoting ill-will is a prerogative for positive change to happen in society, especially if the issue at hand were initially controversial." In the hearing, Yee's defence lawyers Ervin Tan sought to challenge the understanding of the word "obscene" in relation to the charge against Yee for circulating obscene imagery. Another of his lawyers Alfred Dodwell was allowed to admit one more exhibit that he said would "vindicate his client". While the prosecution initially challenged this, the judge allowed its submission, to applause from members of the public in court.{{cite web|title = Verdict in blogger Amos Yee's trial due Tuesday|url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/judge-to-deliver/1833616.html|accessdate = 16 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150515023621/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/judge-to-deliver/1833616.html|archive-date = 15 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Amongst the court documents was the revelation that Yee knew that the contents of his blogs and videos would be offensive, but went ahead with posting them. Yee had said that he was "aware that the content of the video was offensive and would promote feelings of disharmony and ill-will within the Christian community". Yee's trial drew international attention. The [[Wall Street Journal]] writes that Yee's trial showcases "Singapore's struggle to adapt its tradition of censorship to the realities of the digital era."{{cite news |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/teen-youtube-rant-tests-singapores-censorship-limits-1431081983 |title= Teen YouTube Rant Tests Singapore's Censorship Limits |work= The Wall Street Journal |location= Singapore |date= 31 March 2015 |accessdate= 8 May 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150510203258/http://www.wsj.com/articles/teen-youtube-rant-tests-singapores-censorship-limits-1431081983 |archive-date= 10 May 2015 |dead-url= no |df= dmy-all }} === Verdict === The court found Yee guilty and convicted him of both charges on 12 May 2015. With regards to the obscenity charge, judge Jasvender Kaur said that "standards of obscenity will change from time to time", and differ among countries, and that "it was up to the courts to decide based on community standards." Kaur considered the effect that image had on teenagers, and concluded that it met the "strongest possible disapproval and condemnation". With regards to the second charge on making remarks intending to hurt the feelings of Christians, Kaur said that Yee's remarks were "clearly derogatory and offensive to Christians".{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/courts-crime/story/amos-yee-find-out-verdict-his-case-tuesday-afternoon-20150512|title=Amos Yee found guilty of both charges, sentencing on June 2 pending probation report|access-date=12 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150513214609/http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/courts-crime/story/amos-yee-find-out-verdict-his-case-tuesday-afternoon-20150512|archive-date=13 May 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Yee's bail was reduced to $10,000, and his parents paid the bail. The prohibition for him to post online was lifted. Yee was required to remove the offensive YouTube video and the blog post in question; it is not an offence, however, for other people to re-post Yee's videos or blog post.
