Yee also described his interactions with Law and explained how he plotted to publicly humiliate Law while he was in remand prison. When asked about Yee's latest about-turn, Law replied that he thought "it's best to leave Amos alone and not write about him."{{cite web|title = Amos Yee does an about-turn over apology|url = http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-does-about-turn-over-apology|accessdate = 18 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150518183530/http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-does-about-turn-over-apology|archive-date = 18 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} He added that he was not considering legal action. Law's son, Francis Micah Law, took to Facebook to refute Yee's claims against his father.{{cite web|title = Vincent Law's son defends father from Amos|url = http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/05/18/vincent-laws-son-defends-father-from-amos/|accessdate = 18 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150519095949/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/05/18/vincent-laws-son-defends-father-from-amos/#|archive-date = 19 May 2015|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}}{{cite web|title = Amos Yee makes fun of former bailor despite promising to apologise, prompts Vincent Law's son to defend his father|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/more-singapore-stories/story/amos-yee-extremely-remorseful-bailor-allegations-molest-|website = Straits Times|accessdate = 18 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150517023939/http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/more-singapore-stories/story/amos-yee-extremely-remorseful-bailor-allegations-molest-|archive-date = 17 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}}{{cite web|title = It's best to leave teen blogger alone, says former bailor – Regional {{!}} The Star Online|url = http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Regional/2015/05/18/Its-best-to-leave-teen-blogger-alone-says-former-bailor/|accessdate = 18 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150519023538/http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Regional/2015/05/18/Its-best-to-leave-teen-blogger-alone-says-former-bailor/|archive-date = 19 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} In it, he stated that his father always "painted a positive portrayal of Amos in hopes that he would improve the public opinion of Amos." Yee's accusations against Law caused anger among social media users.{{cite web|title = Give me 3 days to pen apology, Amos begs|url = http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/05/15/give-me-3-days-to-pen-apology-amos-begs/|accessdate = 16 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150516192736/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2015/05/15/give-me-3-days-to-pen-apology-amos-begs/#|archive-date = 16 May 2015|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}} Vivekanandan of Free Malaysia Today writes that Yee's Facebook post was "derisive", "acerbic", and "sarcastic". It also charged that with his Facebook post, Yee was guilty of "mocking Christianity again". Carlton Tan of Asian Correspondent expressed his sadness that Yee had gone down this road, and said that he "[does] not support [Yee's] contempt towards the fundamental dignity of other persons."{{cite web|title = Amos Yee retracts apology, claims bailor 'technically' molested him|url = http://asiancorrespondent.com/132942/amos-yee-retracts-apology-claims-bailor-technically-molested-him/|website = asiancorrespondent.com|accessdate = 16 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150518183815/http://asiancorrespondent.com/132942/amos-yee-retracts-apology-claims-bailor-technically-molested-him/|archive-date = 18 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} === Sentencing === On 27 May 2015, Yee was called back to court for an urgent hearing as he refused to meet with his assigned probation officer. The prosecution called for a report to assess Yee's suitability for reformative training, arguing that a jail term or a fine would have no rehabilitative effect.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee should be sent to Reformative Training Centre: Prosecution|url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-to-return-to/1874696.html|accessdate = 27 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150626113031/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-to-return-to/1874696.html|archive-date = 26 June 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}}{{cite web|title = Prosecution seeks reformative training for Amos Yee|url = http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/prosecution-seeking-reformative-training-amos-yee-who-has-made-public-offending-content|accessdate = 27 May 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150531052819/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/prosecution-seeking-reformative-training-amos-yee-who-has-made-public-offending-content|archive-date = 31 May 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} On 2 June Yee was remanded for three weeks and a report was made to assess whether Yee was suitable to serve reformative training.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee trial: Teen blogger remanded for 3 weeks|url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-trial-teen/1886442.html|accessdate = 24 June 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150626121752/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-trial-teen/1886442.html|archive-date = 26 June 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} For this remand period, no bail option was offered. This decision came after Yee rejected the option of probation and instead pleaded for a jail term. The prosecution has argued that Yee's re-uploading of the image and video pertaining to his charges should be taken into account as an indication of his conduct and character.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee back in prison for 3 weeks; to be assessed for reformative training|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/courts-crime/story/amos-yee-back-court-tuesday-morning-sentencing-20150602|website = Straits Times|accessdate = 24 June 2015|first = OLIVIA|last = HO|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150626163852/http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/courts-crime/story/amos-yee-back-court-tuesday-morning-sentencing-20150602|archive-date = 26 June 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} During Yee's remand, new posts emerged on Yee's Facebook page.{{cite web|title = Jailed in Singapore for Criticizing a Former Prime Minister, But Still Blogging|url = https://globalvoicesonline.org/2015/06/30/jailed-in-singapore-for-criticizing-a-former-prime-minister-but-still-blogging/|website = Global Voices|accessdate = 1 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150703040519/http://globalvoicesonline.org/2015/06/30/jailed-in-singapore-for-criticizing-a-former-prime-minister-but-still-blogging/|archive-date = 3 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Amongst them were comparisons of Yee to "figures of martyrdom such as Gandi and Nelson Mandela, as well as complaints about life in prison. One post lamented the lack of exposure to sunshine, while others criticise the attitudes of police officers, such as towards Yee's opting for vegetarian meals.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee in remand but Facebook posts appear|url = http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-remand-facebook-posts-appear|accessdate = 25 June 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150623043229/http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-remand-facebook-posts-appear|archive-date = 23 June 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} The posts intrigued the media{{cite web|title = Amos Yee in remand but his Facebook page continues to get updated mysteriously|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/courts-crime/story/amos-yee-prison-his-facebook-page-continues-get-updated-mysterious|website = Straits Times|accessdate = 25 June 2015|first = OLIVIA|last = HO|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150626155127/http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/courts-crime/story/amos-yee-prison-his-facebook-page-continues-get-updated-mysterious|archive-date = 26 June 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} and public since the Singapore Prison Service has confirmed that all inmates and remandees do not have access to any telecommunication devices within the prison.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee in remand but his Facebook page continues to get updated mysteriously|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/courts-crime/story/amos-yee-prison-his-facebook-page-continues-get-updated-mysterious|website = Straits Times|accessdate = 24 June 2015|first = OLIVIA|last = HO|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150623053232/http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/courts-crime/story/amos-yee-prison-his-facebook-page-continues-get-updated-mysterious|archive-date = 23 June 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} In response, one of Yee's lawyers, Chong, said that they weren't aware of how this is happening and didn't "want to speculate." ====Remand==== On 23 June 2015 district judge Kaur ordered that Yee be remanded at the Institute of Mental Health for two weeks{{cite web|title = Amos Yee remanded at IMH for 2 weeks|url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-remanded-at-imh/1934264.html|accessdate = 24 June 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150623082145/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-remanded-at-imh/1934264.html|archive-date = 23 June 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} in response to a report by Dr Munidasa Winslow who said that Yee may suffer from autism-spectrum disorder.{{cite web|title = Autism spectrum disorder: Fixated preferences could be a sign|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/more-singapore-stories/story/amos-yee-may-have-autism-spectrum-disorder-fixated-prefe|website = Straits Times|accessdate = 25 June 2015|first = JOAN|last = CHEW}} The reformative training suitability report found Yee physically and mentally suitable for reformative training. Kaur reported that she was exploring other sentencing options, such as a mandatory treatment order, which would compel Yee to undergo psychiatric treatment. At the Institute for Mental Health, Yee was evaluated by psychiatrist Cai Yi Ming,{{cite web|title = Sentence backdated, Amos Yee released|url = http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/sentence-backdated-amos-yee-released|accessdate = 7 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150710015957/http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/sentence-backdated-amos-yee-released|archive-date = 10 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} who said that Yee "promised not to re-offend as he realised what he did was against the law and could disrupt social harmony". Contrary to the suspicions that Winslow had, Cai's report concluded that Yee does not suffer from any mental disorder, and would benefit from having a counsellor or mentor guide him in using the Internet.{{cite web|title = Sentence backdated, Amos Yee released - Regional {{!}} The Star Online|url = http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Regional/2015/07/07/Amos-Yee-Released/|website = www.thestar.com.my|accessdate = 7 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150707203821/http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Regional/2015/07/07/Amos-Yee-Released/|archive-date = 7 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} He added that Yee was "trapped in the Net" and is "unable to discern untruths in cyberspace". ====Sentence criticism==== Yee's sentence was met with criticism from the United Nations Human Rights Office which called for the immediate release of Yee in line with its commitment under the UN Convention on the Rights of Child.{{cite web|title = UN Urges Singapore To Release 16-Year-Old Blogger Amos Yee: UPDATED|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/jnylander/2015/06/23/un-urges-singapore-to-release-16-year-old-blogger-accused-of-posting-critical-lee-kuan-yew-photos/|accessdate = 24 June 2015|first = Johan|last = Nylander|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150623073304/http://www.forbes.com/sites/jnylander/2015/06/23/un-urges-singapore-to-release-16-year-old-blogger-accused-of-posting-critical-lee-kuan-yew-photos/|archive-date = 23 June 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} It said that "while recognizing the Singapore authorities concern with public morality and social harmony, OHCHR is concerned that the criminal sanctions considered in this case seem disproportionate and inappropriate in terms of the international protections for freedom of expression and opinion." The group appealed to the Singapore authorities to give special considerations to Yee's juvenile status and ensure that his treatment with the best interests of the child. Yee's sentence was also met with criticism from the Humans Rights Watch. Phil Robertson, deputy Asia director said that "nothing that Amos Yee said or posted should ever have been considered criminal – much less merit incarceration." He went on the say that "the dismal state of Singapore's respect for free expression can be seen in the decision to impose the criminal justice system on outspoken 16-year-olds". In response to the mandatory psychiatric treatment that Yee is ordered to undergo, Robertson said that "The court has provided no adequate justification for Yee's further detention and has ordered forced psychiatric tests."{{cite web|title = Singapore: Exonerate 16-Year-Old Blogger {{!}} Human Rights Watch|url = https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/06/22/singapore-exonerate-16-year-old-blogger|publisher = Human Rights Watch|accessdate = 24 June 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150624015311/http://www.hrw.org/news/2015/06/22/singapore-exonerate-16-year-old-blogger|archive-date = 24 June 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Yee's sentence was met with opposition from within Singapore. Singaporean politician [[Goh Meng Seng]] said that even though he did not like Amos "because he's rude in the Singapore context", he felt that "he [had] to defend his rights." Singaporean academic Cherian George, lawyer Peter Low, a former president of the Law Society of Singapore, as well as leading rights activists, academics, filmmakers and members of the arts community signed a letter saying that they were "troubled by the State’s harsh reactions and that "sending Yee to the facility could deter young people in the city-state from expressing their views openly for fear of reprisals.{{cite web|title = Singapore activists, human rights groups denounce 'harsh' treatment of Amos Yee|url = http://www.themalaymailonline.com/world/article/singapore-activists-human-rights-groups-denounce-harsh-treatment-of-amos-ye|accessdate = 5 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150707135556/http://www.themalaymailonline.com/world/article/singapore-activists-human-rights-groups-denounce-harsh-treatment-of-amos-ye|archive-date = 7 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Also, an open letter expressing concerns about the way Yee was treated was signed by 77 individuals, including civil society activist Braema Mathi, playwright Alfan Sa'at and academic Cherian George, saying that Yee's prosecution has created a "negative impact on his well-being and that of his family".{{cite web|title = Open letter over state's treatment of Amos Yee sent to PM|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/open-letter-over-states-treatment-of-amos-yee-sent-to-pm|accessdate = 5 July 2015|first = DANSON|last = CHEONG|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150706171125/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/open-letter-over-states-treatment-of-amos-yee-sent-to-pm|archive-date = 6 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Meanwhile, Yee's mother apologised to Yee on her own Facebook profile{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/mary.toh.927/posts/107008039641495 |title=Mary Toh - Sorry Son. Sorry for telling you that you are… |publisher=Facebook |date=28 June 2015 |accessdate=13 April 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150914233350/https://www.facebook.com/mary.toh.927/posts/107008039641495 |archive-date=14 September 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} with a "heartfelt apology letter", saying that she was wrong and sorry for telling Yee that he was in "the safest country".{{cite news|title = Singapore mom of detained teen Amos Yee: 'Sorry, son' - CNN.com|url = http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/30/asia/singapore-amos-yee-mother-sorry/index.html|website = CNN|accessdate = 1 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150701145944/http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/30/asia/singapore-amos-yee-mother-sorry/index.html|archive-date = 1 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}}{{cite web|title = Detained blogger's mother apologises to her son|url = http://www.gazettetribune.com/detained-bloggers-mother-apologises-to-her-son/1955/|accessdate = 1 July 2015|first = Clark|last = Smith|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150702031446/http://www.gazettetribune.com/detained-bloggers-mother-apologises-to-her-son/1955/|archive-date = 2 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} ====Hospitalisation==== On 5 July 2015, the night before Yee's next hearing was scheduled to be held, Yee was admitted to the [[Emergency department|Accident and Emergency department]] at [[Changi Hospital]]{{cite web|title = Amos Yee sent to hospital|url = http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/07/amos-yee-sent-to-hospital/|accessdate = 6 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150705200851/http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/07/amos-yee-sent-to-hospital/|archive-date = 5 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} for low [[blood glucose]] levels. According to his mother, Yee had not been eating for several days, was not sleeping well and feeling depressed.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee trial plagued by last-minute hospitalisation, growing protests|url = https://sg.news.yahoo.com/amos-yee-trial-plagued-last-230340825.html|accessdate = 6 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150824123032/https://sg.news.yahoo.com/amos-yee-trial-plagued-last-230340825.html|archive-date = 24 August 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Earlier, on 12 June Yee's lawyer reported that Yee had been experiencing suicidal thoughts at the prospect of reformative training. While Yee had been initially "very courteous and engaged in the process", his stint at the Institute for Mental Health had been "a shock to his system". On 6 July Yee was sentenced to four weeks in jail, one week for posting obscene materials and three weeks for wounding the religious feelings of Christian in his video calling Lee Kuan Yew a “horrible person”, with the sentences to be served consecutively.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee, Singaporean teenager who berated founding father Lee Kuan Yew in online video, given 4 weeks in jail|url = http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/1834003/amos-yee-singaporean-teenager-who-berated-founding-father|accessdate = 6 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150706190229/http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/1834003/amos-yee-singaporean-teenager-who-berated-founding-father|archive-date = 6 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} He was addressed directly by the judge Kaur who said that she hopes that Yee would "rethink long and hard his decision not to continue with formal education," before acknowledging that there are few dropout success stories. Yee was released immediately after his sentences were announced as they were backdated to 2 June when he was in remand (Yee was in remand for 50 days). Yee's demeanor when he was freed differed from his previous court appearances. Yee appeared pale and gaunt, wore a frown on his face and kept his head bowed most of the time. In court, Deputy Public Prosecutor Hay Hung Chun said that they saw Yee's actions as "no less than a significant repudiation of his previous posturing, and it is an important acknowledgment that he has finally accepted the gravity of what he had done and that he was or is willing now to make amends by undoing it.” This was in response to Institute of Mental Health child psychiatrist Cai Yiming's report that Yee had admitted to his guilt and has “realised what he has done was against the law and could disrupt social harmony”. As a result of the change which Hay describes as "seismic", Hay announced that the prosecution would be asking for just one day of imprisonment.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee released after 4-week jail term is backdated|url = http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/teenage-blogger-amos-yee-sentenced-four-weeks-jail|accessdate = 6 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150707222206/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/teenage-blogger-amos-yee-sentenced-four-weeks-jail|archive-date = 7 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Upon his release, Yee began to ask for cash donations.{{cite web|title = Traumatized Amos Yee is open for Donation|url = http://www.freedistrict.com/asia/singapore-2-asia/traumatized-amos-yee-open-donation-9983.html|accessdate = 23 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150723174220/http://www.freedistrict.com/asia/singapore-2-asia/traumatized-amos-yee-open-donation-9983.html|archive-date = 23 July 2015|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}} Calling the four-week jail sentence a "dark day for freedom of expression" in Singapore,{{cite web|title = Singapore: Amos Yee sentence a dark day for freedom of expression {{!}} Amnesty International|url = https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2015/07/singapore-amos-yee-sentence-a-dark-day-for-freedom-of-expression/|website = www.amnesty.org|accessdate = 7 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150708051854/https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2015/07/singapore-amos-yee-sentence-a-dark-day-for-freedom-of-expression/|archive-date = 8 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Amnesty International charges that the sentence violates the right to freedom of expression and should be quashed.{{cite web|title = Amos Yee's sentence: A dark day for freedom of expression|url = http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/07/amos-yees-sentence-a-dark-day-for-freedom-of-expression/|accessdate = 7 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150707073417/http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/07/amos-yees-sentence-a-dark-day-for-freedom-of-expression/|archive-date = 7 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Rupert Abbott, South East Asia and the Pacific Deputy Director said that “Amos Yee is not a criminal. He should never have been charged, let alone convicted. He has been punished solely for exercising his right to freedom of expression." He added that "if there is any justice Amos Yee would be walking free from court without a conviction against his name.” [[The Online Citizen]] calls the conviction "wrong" and describes the sentence as "manifestly excessive".{{cite web|title = Conviction wrong, sentence manifestly excessive: Amos Yee|url = http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/07/conviction-wrong-sentence-manifestly-excessive-amos-yee/|accessdate = 7 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150707130805/http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/07/conviction-wrong-sentence-manifestly-excessive-amos-yee/|archive-date = 7 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Writer and gender equality activist Jolene Tan accused the prosecution for "[focusing] overwhelmingly on Amos’ attitudes rather than any harm that was done by his supposed crimes." She questioned the motive of the sentence, asking whether it was "justice for a crime", or "just as a way to quash Amos into docility.” The [[Association of Women for Action and Research]] criticised the court decision and urged the state to be mindful of the "stigmatising effect of such prosecutions in the future".{{cite web|title = AWARE statement on the prosecution of Amos Yee|url = http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/07/aware-statement-on-the-prosecution-of-amos-yee-2/|accessdate = 23 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150723172433/http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/07/aware-statement-on-the-prosecution-of-amos-yee-2/|archive-date = 23 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}}{{cite web|url = http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/aware-expresses-grave-concerns-over-amos-yee-case|title = AWARE expresses grave concerns over Amos Yee case|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} === Protests against treatment of Yee === Yee's sentence led to protests from several activist groups. On 27 June 2015 about sixty people under the banner of the [[Taiwan Association for Human Rights]] demonstrated outside the Singapore Trade Office in Taipei.{{cite web|title = About 60 demonstrate outside S'pore Trade Office in Taipei; call for Amos Yee's release|url = http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/about-60-demonstrate-outside-spore-trade-office-taipei-call-amos-yees-release|accessdate = 1 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150701092455/http://news.asiaone.com/news/singapore/about-60-demonstrate-outside-spore-trade-office-taipei-call-amos-yees-release|archive-date = 1 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} The protesters from more than 10 civil society groups under the banner of the Taiwan Association for Human Rights (TAHR) held placards and chanted "Free Amos Yee" for about half an hour. [[File:Free Amos Yee 1.jpg|thumb|Hong Kong students protest to release Amos Yee]] On 30 June university students in [[Hong Kong]] held a protest to urge the Singapore government to release Yee. Student activist group Scholarism, which took part in the protest, published a post asserting that the actions taken against Yee "reflects the unreasonable oppression and the very limited acceptance of dynamic voices in the so-called 'modernised' society of Singapore.{{cite web|title = Hong Kong students protest near Singapore consulate urging Amos Yee's release|url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/hong-kong-students/1952510.html|accessdate = 1 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150911023107/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/hong-kong-students/1952510.html|archive-date = 11 September 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}}{{cite web|title = Release Singaporean teen blogger Amos Yee, Hong Kong student group Scholarism urges|url = http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/1829377/singapore-should-release-teen-blogger-amos-yee-hong-kong|accessdate = 1 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150702070403/http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/1829377/singapore-should-release-teen-blogger-amos-yee-hong-kong|archive-date = 2 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}}{{cite web|title = Hong Kong students protest outside Singapore consulate, urge release of Amos Yee, East Asia News & Top Stories - The Straits Times|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/hong-kong-student-group-scholarism-urges-release-of-amos-yee-petition-planned-outside|accessdate = 1 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150701193241/http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/hong-kong-student-group-scholarism-urges-release-of-amos-yee-petition-planned-outside|archive-date = 1 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} On 5 July a demonstration was held in Hong Kong, where protestors burnt [[effigies]] of [[Lee Hsien Loong]] and [[Lee Kuan Yew]], to demand the release of Yee. About 50 people from various civic and political groups gathered with banners and placards near the Singapore Consulate in Admiralty district.{{cite web|title = Protesters in Hong Kong demand release of Singaporean teen Amos Yee|url = http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/1832719/admiralty-protesters-demand-release-singaporean-teen-amos|accessdate = 5 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150706172417/http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/1832719/admiralty-protesters-demand-release-singaporean-teen-amos|archive-date = 6 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} They held banners and placards that read "Dissident is not Demented" and "Freedom of Speech should not be infringed". Also on 5 July in Singapore, a rally organised by Community Action Network, a group of individuals describing themselves as "concerned about freedom of expression in Singapore", was attended by an estimated 500 people. The rally was held to demand the release of Yee.{{cite web|title = Rally at Hong Lim Park calls for Amos Yee's release|url = http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/rally-hong-lim-park-calls-amos-yees-release|accessdate = 5 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150706141639/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/rally-hong-lim-park-calls-amos-yees-release|archive-date = 6 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} The organisers of the protest were "damning" in their condemnation of the state’s handling of Yee’s case. Jolovan Wham, a social worker and civil activist said that “[the activists] came together to protest what the government is doing to Amos Yee, and to take a stand on freedom of expression,” citing "an unprecedented crackdown on freedom of expression in Singapore” in the last few years. === Appeal against conviction and sentence === Yee filed an appeal against the conviction and sentence, ahead of 20 July 2015 deadline for making an appeal.{{cite web|title = Singaporean blogger Amos Yee appeals against conviction, sentence|url = http://www.themalaymailonline.com/world/article/singaporean-blogger-amos-yee-appealing-against-conviction-sentence|accessdate = 23 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150723184253/http://www.themalaymailonline.com/world/article/singaporean-blogger-amos-yee-appealing-against-conviction-sentence|archive-date = 23 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Yee's lawyer, Dodwell, said that "whether this was a crime or not still remains a question [that they wanted to] determine in the high court".{{cite web|title = Amos Yee files appeal against conviction and sentence|url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-files-appeal/1995234.html|accessdate = 23 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150722175126/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/amos-yee-files-appeal/1995234.html|archive-date = 22 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} Yee's mother said that she wanted "to know for sure that what Amos has done is not criminally wrong".{{cite web|title = Teen blogger Amos Yee files appeal|url = http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/305598|website = www.malaysiakini.com|accessdate = 23 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150723172940/http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/305598|archive-date = 23 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} For the hearing at the High Court, Yee's lawyers want the appeal to be heard by a non-Christian judge.{{cite web|title = Lawyers want judge who's not Christian for Amos Yee appeal|url = http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/lawyers-want-judge-whos-not-christian-for-amos-yee-appeal|accessdate = 23 July 2015|first = OLIVIA|last = HO|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150723200453/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/lawyers-want-judge-whos-not-christian-for-amos-yee-appeal|archive-date = 23 July 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} ==Second offence for hurting religious feelings, arrest and conviction== In his post on 27 November 2015, Amos addressed [[Calvin Cheng]]'s comments on killing the children of terrorist members. He wrote, "Oh yes and **** [[Islam]], and Allah doesn’t exist, but say you see a prick from ISIS who wants to kill or has even killed before, don't think that's a scenario where it's alright to kill him."{{cite web|url=https://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2016/05/24/timeline-of-amos-yees-latest-arrest-by-the-singapore-police-force-over-section-298-of-penal-code/|title=Timeline of Amos Yee's latest arrest by the Singapore Police Force over Section 298 of penal code - The Online Citizen|date=24 May 2016|publisher=|access-date=19 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180824101839/https://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2016/05/24/timeline-of-amos-yees-latest-arrest-by-the-singapore-police-force-over-section-298-of-penal-code/|archive-date=24 August 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} His statement prompted several police reports from the public,{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Min Kok|title=Singaporean, 17, believed to be blogger Amos Yee, investigated for allegedly offensive religious remarks|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/singaporean-17-believed-to-be-blogger-amos-yee-investigated-for-allegedly|accessdate=16 March 2016|publisher=Straits Times|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160320085950/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/singaporean-17-believed-to-be-blogger-amos-yee-investigated-for-allegedly|archive-date=20 March 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title = Amos Yee to be interviewed by police for offensive remarks|url = http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/amos-yee-be-interviewed-police-offensive-remarks|accessdate = 16 December 2015|date = 16 December 2015|website = TODAYonline|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151218090155/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/amos-yee-be-interviewed-police-offensive-remarks|archive-date = 18 December 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}} and subsequent police investigation in December 2015 for allegedly posting offensive material on his blog. On 13 May 2016, it was reported in the Straits Times that Yee was arrested on 11 May for ''allegedly uttering words last November with a deliberate intent to wound religious or racial feelings'' and for ''[[Unsupervised probation|not showing up at a police station]]''. He was subsequently bailed.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/blogger-amos-yee-arrested-again-0|title=Blogger Amos Yee arrested again|last=Yang|first=Calvin|date=13 May 2016|website=[[The Straits Times]]|access-date=13 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160514104326/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/blogger-amos-yee-arrested-again-0|archive-date=14 May 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ===Trial=== On 17 August 2016, Yee stood trial over six charges for deliberate intent to wound religious feelings and two charges for failure to turn up for police interviews. He was not represented by a lawyer. Seven police officers were summoned as prosection's witnesses.{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/amos-yee-back-in-court-over-offensive-videos|title=Amos Yee back in court over offensive videos|first=|last=hermes|date=18 August 2016|publisher=|access-date=11 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171111205635/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/amos-yee-back-in-court-over-offensive-videos|archive-date=11 November 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Before the trial could proceed further, Yee was granted permission to go for Criminal Case Resolution process.{{cite web|url=https://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2016/08/17/amos-yee-represents-himself-in-court-to-stand-trial-against-8-charges/|title=Amos Yee represents himself in court to stand trial against 8 charges - The Online Citizen|date=17 August 2016|publisher=|access-date=11 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171111204958/https://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2016/08/17/amos-yee-represents-himself-in-court-to-stand-trial-against-8-charges/|archive-date=11 November 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ===Sentencing=== On 29 September 2016, Amos Yee was sentenced to 6 weeks' jail and fined $2000 for wounding religious feelings.{{cite news|last1=Siau|first1=Ming En|title=Amos Yee jailed 6 weeks, fined for hurting religious feelings|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/amos-yee-jailed-6-weeks-fined-s2000-over-religious-insults|accessdate=25 December 2016|work=TODAYonline|date=29 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161225145152/http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/amos-yee-jailed-6-weeks-fined-s2000-over-religious-insults|archive-date=25 December 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The presiding judge, Ong Hian Sun, said that Yee had "deliberately elected to do harm" in a photograph and two videos he posted online that were said to have "offensive and insulting words and profane gestures to hurt the feelings of Christians and Muslims".{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/09/singapore-jails-amos-yee-religious-insult-160929205613910.html |title=Singapore jails Amos Yee for religious 'insult' - News from |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=29 September 2016 |accessdate=13 April 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170412190640/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/09/singapore-jails-amos-yee-religious-insult-160929205613910.html |archive-date=12 April 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Ong said that Yee's actions could "generate social unrest" and should not be condoned.{{cite web|last1=Fathin Ungku|title=Singapore court sends teen blogger back to jail for criticizing religion|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-singapore-teen-verdict-idUSKCN11Z0DW|website=Reuters|accessdate=6 March 2017|date=29 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170306133344/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-singapore-teen-verdict-idUSKCN11Z0DW|archive-date=6 March 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Yee began serving his jail term on 13 October 2016.{{cite news|last1=Amir Hussain|title=Blogger Amos Yee starts serving 6-week jail term|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/blogger-amos-yee-starts-serving-6-week-jail-term|accessdate=25 December 2016|work=[[The Straits Times]]|date=13 October 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161225145841/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/blogger-amos-yee-starts-serving-6-week-jail-term|archive-date=25 December 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} He spent 21 days at Tanah Merah Prison. His request for home detention was successful, so he served the remainder of his jail term at home.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} == Life in US == On 16 December 2016, Amos Yee fled to the United States where he was detained at Chicago's [[O'Hare International Airport|O'Hare Airport]] after announcing his intention to seek political asylum. During the application, he was incarcerated in [[McHenry County, Illinois|McHenry County]] Jail in [[Illinois]].{{cite web |author=Rachel Au-Yongrachelay |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/teenage-blogger-amos-yee-detained-in-united-states |title=Teenage blogger Amos Yee detained in United States, Singapore News & Top Stories |publisher=The Straits Times |date=23 December 2016 |accessdate=13 April 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230204424/http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/teenage-blogger-amos-yee-detained-in-united-states |archive-date=30 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} He was subsequently transferred to [[Dodge County, Wisconsin|Dodge County]] Detention Facility in [[Wisconsin]].{{cite web |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/world/united-states/us-judge-grants-amos-yees-asylum-request |title=US judge grants Amos Yee's asylum request, United States News & Top Stories |publisher=The Straits Times |date=25 March 2017 |accessdate=13 April 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170408200808/http://www.straitstimes.com/world/united-states/us-judge-grants-amos-yees-asylum-request |archive-date=8 April 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Yee was granted asylum in the US on 24 March 2017, after the judge ruled that Yee faced persecution in Singapore for his political opinions; the judge cited the different ways that [[Calvin Cheng|Cheng]] and Yee were treated in his decision.{{cite news |last1=Philemon |first1=Jewel |title=Amos Yee is deserving of asylum, US Board of Immigration Appeal rules |url=http://www.theindependent.sg/amos-yee-is-deserving-of-asylum-us-board-of-immigration-appeal-rules/ |work=The Independent |location=Singapore |date=26 September 2017 |access-date=5 November 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107015822/http://www.theindependent.sg/amos-yee-is-deserving-of-asylum-us-board-of-immigration-appeal-rules/ |archive-date=7 November 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |title=Teen blogger Amos Yee granted US asylum |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/teen-blogger-amos-yee-granted-us-asylum/3624426.html |accessdate=25 March 2017 |work=Channel NewsAsia |location=Singapore |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170325023808/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/teen-blogger-amos-yee-granted-us-asylum/3624426.html |archive-date=25 March 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Yee was due to serve his national service upon reaching 18 years old in October 2016.{{cite news |title=Singapore blogger seeking U.S. asylum regrets posts in home country |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-singapore-blogger-idUSKBN14J1ZC |accessdate=25 March 2017 |publisher=Reuters |date=30 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170326055355/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-singapore-blogger-idUSKBN14J1ZC |archive-date=26 March 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} By leaving Singapore, Yee breached Singaporean law which mandates [[National service in Singapore|compulsory military service]] for all Singaporean men.{{cite news |title=Singapore teen blogger Amos Yee granted US asylum |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-39388810 |accessdate=25 March 2017 |work=BBC News |date=25 March 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170325032956/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-39388810 |archive-date=25 March 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} On 25 April 2017, the U.S. government appealed against the decision to grant Yee asylum, so he continued to be held at the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) center during the appeal process. On his reasons for seeking U.S. asylum, Reuters reported that although Yee was highly critical of the U.S. government abroad, he has said that - "It is not going to the best country. This is about going to the country that most effectively promotes my political philosophy of [[anarchist communism|anarchical communism]] and ending private property and wage labor". Amos Yee was released from a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in downtown Chicago on 26 September 2017 following an immigration appeals court's decision to uphold his bid for asylum. A Board of Immigration Appeals decision upheld Chicago immigration judge Samuel Cole's March ruling that Yee had a "well-founded fear" of being persecuted upon return to Singapore. The judge said the aim of jailing Yee in Singapore at such a young age was to stifle his political speech. With asylum status, Yee will be eligible to apply for a green card in a year. Yee told reporters after his release that he can now criticise the Singaporean government without fear of imprisonment, and that while he planned to make more critical videos on the topic, he might also broaden his work to US politics since he is in the country.{{cite news|title=Singaporean blogger released after winning U.S. ruling for asylum|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-singapore-blogger/singaporean-blogger-released-after-winning-u-s-ruling-for-asylum-idUSKCN1C12WW|accessdate=27 September 2017|publisher=Reuters|date=27 September 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170926234641/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-singapore-blogger/singaporean-blogger-released-after-winning-u-s-ruling-for-asylum-idUSKCN1C12WW|archive-date=26 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In November 2017, The Open Campus Initiative, a student club at [[Harvard College]],{{cite news|last1=Bishai|first1=Graham W|title=With Provocative Speakers, New Group Aims to ‘Test’ Free Speech Values|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2017/4/7/free-speech-club/|work=The Harvard Crimson|date=17 April 2017|language=en|access-date=23 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171122230735/http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2017/4/7/free-speech-club/|archive-date=22 November 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} invited Yee to give a talk and then cancelled it less than 24 hours before the event.{{cite news |last1=Philemon |first1=Jewel |title=Amos Yee set to give first ever public talk at Harvard |url=http://www.theindependent.sg/amos-yee-set-to-give-first-ever-public-talk-at-harvard/ |work=The Independent |location=Singapore |date=11 November 2017 |access-date=17 November 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117175311/http://www.theindependent.sg/amos-yee-set-to-give-first-ever-public-talk-at-harvard/ |archive-date=17 November 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |title=Harvard cancels Amos Yee's lecture |url=http://www.theindependent.sg/harvard-cancels-amos-yees-lecture/ |work=The Independent |location=Singapore |date=12 November 2017 |access-date=23 November 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171115150711/http://www.theindependent.sg/harvard-cancels-amos-yees-lecture/ |archive-date=15 November 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} According to Yee, his talk was likely cancelled due to older videos he had created in support of removing the age of consent for sex.{{cite web |title=Why Pedophilia Is Alright |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2wtlN8ZIzc4 |website=YouTube |date=15 November 2017 |access-date=2 March 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171116011151/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2wtlN8ZIzc4 |archive-date=16 November 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} He had by that point run short of money, and asked for donations from his followers via Facebook, saying that he would rather borrow than take a job he did not like.{{cite news |url=http://www.theindependent.sg/amos-yee-prefers-handouts-than-finding-a-job-resorts-to-crowdfunding-online-to-survive-in-us/ |title=Amos Yee prefers handouts than finding a job; resorts to crowdfunding online to survive in US |work=The Independent |location=Singapore |date=3 November 2017 |access-date=29 November 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201040124/http://www.theindependent.sg/amos-yee-prefers-handouts-than-finding-a-job-resorts-to-crowdfunding-online-to-survive-in-us/ |archive-date=1 December 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Shortly after his appeal for donations, he was banned from Facebook for 30 days for violating Facebook's community standards.{{cite news |url= http://www.theindependent.sg/amos-yee-is-banned-from-facebook/ |title= Amos Yee is banned from Facebook |work= The Independent |location= Singapore |date= 30 November 2017 |access-date= 29 November 2017 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20171201035525/http://www.theindependent.sg/amos-yee-is-banned-from-facebook/ |archive-date= 1 December 2017 |dead-url= no |df= dmy-all }} Twitter suspended his account sometime in 2017.{{cite news |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/2145142/youtube-terminates-singapore-blogger-amos-yees-account |title=YouTube terminates Singapore blogger Amos Yee's account for violating community guidelines |newspaper=South China Morning Post |location=Hong Kong |date=8 May 2018 |author=Wong Pei-ting |access-date=8 May 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180508185148/http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/2145142/youtube-terminates-singapore-blogger-amos-yees-account |archive-date=8 May 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} In April 2018, the [[Toy Industry Association]] pulled ads from the video streaming platform following a [[CNN]] report its ads had been appearing on Yee's channel, which was being used to promote pedophilia. YouTube subsequently pulled ads from Yee's videos and banned him from monetising content.{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2018/04/19/technology/youtube-ads-extreme-content-investigation/index.html|title=Exclusive: YouTube ran ads from hundreds of brands on extremist channels|first=Paul P. Murphy, Kaya Yurieff and Gianluca|last=Mezzofiore|publisher=|access-date=8 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180511003635/http://money.cnn.com/2018/04/19/technology/youtube-ads-extreme-content-investigation/index.html|archive-date=11 May 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/6100198/youtube-adverts-amazon-facebook-netflix-terrorist-padeophilia-nazi-channels/|title=YouTube running adverts for hundreds of companies including Amazon, Facebook and Netflix on terrorist, paedophilia and Nazi channels|date=20 April 2018|publisher=|access-date=8 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180508185736/https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/6100198/youtube-adverts-amazon-facebook-netflix-terrorist-padeophilia-nazi-channels/|archive-date=8 May 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In early May 2018, YouTube terminated Yee's channel for violating community guidelines.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-44039616|title='Paedophilia-defending' YouTuber removed|date=8 May 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com|access-date=21 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180620035216/https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-44039616|archive-date=20 June 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In July 2018, Yee's Patreon account had also been shut down.{{cite web|url=http://theindependent.sg/looks-like-amos-yee-might-just-be-returning-to-singapore/|title=Looks like Amos Yee might just be returning to Singapore|first=Obbana|last=Rajah|website=The Independent|access-date=21 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180821160535/http://theindependent.sg/looks-like-amos-yee-might-just-be-returning-to-singapore/|archive-date=21 August 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} {{Infobox person |name = Anneke Grönloh |image = Anneke Grönloh color.jpg |birth_date = {{birth date|1942|6|7}} |birth_place = [[Minahasa Regency|Tondano]], [[North Celebes]], [[Netherlands East Indies]] (now [[Indonesia]]) |birth_name = Louise Johanna Grönloh |death_date = {{death date and age|2018|9|14|1942|6|7}} |death_place = France |spouse = Wim-Jaap van der Laan (1964–2004; divorced) |nationality = |residence = |occupation = Singer |yearsactive = 1959–2017 |known_for = |website = |module = {{Infobox musical artist |embed = yes |background = solo_singer |genre = {{hlist|[[Pop music|Pop]]|[[Jazz music|jazz]]|[[folk music|folk]]}} |instrument = [[Vocal]]s }} }} '''Louise Johanna "Anneke" Grönloh''' (7 June 1942 – 14 September 2018) was an Indonesia-born Dutch singer. She had a successful career starting in 1959 that lasted throughout the 1960s, and scored a hit with "Brandend Zand", one of the best-selling Dutch songs of all time. == Life == [[File:Diva Anneke Gronloh.jpg|thumb|Anneke Grönloh in 2007]] Grönloh was born in [[Minahasa Regency|Tondano]], [[North Celebes]], [[Netherlands East Indies]] (now [[Indonesia]]), and spent her early years in the Japanese-occupied Dutch East Indies in a Japanese concentration camp. Her father, an officer in the KNIL, had been [[interned]] before her birth. After the war, the family moved to the Netherlands, and Grönloh grew up in [[Eindhoven]]. At the ''Gemeentelijk Lyceum'' (Municipal College) she met and played with [[Peter Koelewijn]] and his band ''Peter en zijn Rockets'' at parties. In 1959 her career took off after she won a talent show. On 31 August 1964 she married [[Wim-Jaap van der Laan]], a DJ for Dutch radio station [[Radio Veronica]], and in 1965 began singing in the [[Snip en Snap|Sleeswijk Revue]].{{cite web|url=http://www.europopmusic.eu/Holland_pages/Gronloh.html|title=Anneke Gronloh – europopmusic|language=Dutch|accessdate=21 August 2013}} Throughout the 1960s she scored hits, especially with "Brandend Zand" (English: "Burning sand"). At the height of her fame, in 1964, Grönloh took part in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1964|Eurovision Song Contest]] with the song "[[Jij bent mijn leven]]" (English: "You are my life"), which ended with a joint tenth place with the Belgian entry, and by the end of the 1960s she had begun an international singing career. Besides popular music, Grönloh also performed the [[kroncong]] genre, singing songs such as "[[Bengawan Solo (song)|Bengawan Solo]]", "Boeroeng Kakatua", and "Nina Bobo", and also sings jazz, which she claims is her favorite genre. == Singer of the Century== In 2000, Grönloh was named "Singer of the Century" because of the record-breaking sales of "Brandend Zand". In the same year, she was also a participant on the television program [[Big Brother (TV series)|Big Brother VIPS]]. In 2006 she released ''Anneke and Friends'', a DVD of her theater tours. Later that year she was part of the theater tour "Purple 100", replacing [[Corry Brokken]] who could not perform due to illness. == End of career == Grönloh had retired due to health problems; she played her last show on 26 August 2017. == Death == Grönloh died on 14 September 2018, at the age of 76. Reports indicate that she will be laid to rest in France.[https://www.star2.com/entertainment/2018/09/23/singer-anneke-gronloh-dies/ ‘Bengawan Solo’, ‘Asmara’ singer Anneke Gronloh dies] ''Star2'' (September 23, 2018). Retrieved on September 26, 2018. == Discography== *"Asmara" (1960, in Indonesian) *"Flamenco Rock" *"Brandend Zand" (1961) – [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] *"Paradiso" (1962) – went [[Platinum record|platinum]] *"[[Surabaya|Soerabaja]]" (1963) *"Cimeroni" (1963) *"Oh Malaysia" (1963) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Anneke Grönloh}} * {{IMDb name|1486744}} {{s-start}} {{s-ach}} {{succession box | before=[[Annie Palmen]]

with ''"[['t Is genoeg]]"'' | }} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gronloh, Anneke}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:People from Minahasa Regency]] [[Category:Indo people]] [[Category:Dutch Eurovision Song Contest entrants]] [[Category:Dutch female singers]] [[Category:Dutch people of Indonesian descent]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest entrants of 1964]] [[Category:Musicians from Eindhoven]] [[Category:Philips Records artists]]
